parameter.help: The keys in this section deeply affect the operation of the SNOWPACK model. This could lead to unexpected behavior or surprising results. If you are not an experienced Snowpack user, please do NOT change any keys below!

Variant selection. A choice of specific SNOWPACK variants that will set some switches and values to non-default ones. Users can override these by setting them below. When using POLAR variant, please cite: Steger CR, Reijmer CH, van den Broeke MR, Wever N, Forster RR, Koenig LS, Kuipers Munneke P, Lehning M, Lhermitte S, Ligtenberg SRM, Miège C and Noël BPY, "Firn Meltwater Retention on the Greenland Ice Sheet: A Model Comparison", Front. Earth Sci. 5:3, 2017, doi: 10.3389/feart.2017.00003
Except for some very specific operational needs, please choose TRUE (default: TRUE)

If set to true, an adjustment of the height of the meteo values to the presence of a snow cover is applied (e.g., for measurements from a fixed mast that gets snowed in). If false, measured meteo values are assumed to maintain a constant height above the snow surface (e.g., when using measurements from Col de Porte or weather models as input). (default: TRUE)

If set to true, an adjustment of the height of the wind value to the presence of a snow cover is applied (e.g., for measurements from a fixed mast that gets snowed in). If false, measured wind value are assumed to maintain a constant height above the snow surface (e.g., when using weather models as input). (default: TRUE)

Sometimes at the end of the snow melt, there is still some snow left in the simulation but none left in reality. This can be problematic when forcing the model with reflected short wave radiation, because a low measured RSWR (iswr reflected on a dark ground) will be used to generate a low ISWR, resulting in even less snow melt. Setting FORCE_SW_MODE to TRUE allows Snowpack to use the potential ISWR when the remaining snow height is less than 10cm, the relative humidity is low enough and the measured RSWR is very low compared to the potential incoming short wave radiation. (default: FALSE)

Specifies if snow erosion is enabled for the main station. Works only if measured heigths of snow are available at the main station. Unless NUMBER_SLOPES is set to 1, this erosion will not contribute to the drifting snow index (compare with SNOW_REDISTRIBUTION). (default: FALSE)
Scaling factor to apply to wind values causing drifting snow because some stations consistently measure a wind that is too low (this should be computed from statistical analysis). (default: 1.0)

Based on meteorological input from a (flat field) automatic station or numerical weather model, up to 8 expositions can be calculated in addition to the flat field if the corresponding *.sno files are provided. For example, if you provide a flat field *.snow file (mandatory), which is named KLO2.sno and you want 4 slopes to be calculated the corresponding slope files should be named KLO21.sno, . . ., KLO24.sno. SNOW_REDISTRIBUTION is only available if each virtual slope has a matching luv/lee slope.
Set this option if the main station is on a slope and the input parameters are taken perpendicular to the slope. Works only for "NUMBER_SLOPES = 1" (default: FALSE)

Set whether adaptive time stepping is allowed for solving the heat advection equation/phase changes when unstable atmospheric stratification is encountered (only for non-neutral atmospheric stability schemes). It then temporarily reduces the time step, in order to reduce oscillations in surface temperature. This increases computation times. Note that independent of this flag, the time step can be temporarily reduced when the heat equation does not converge (default: TRUE).
Specifies if redistribution of snow is allowed from windward (luv) to lee slopes. The snow erosion on virtual slopes will contribute to the drifting snow index (default: FALSE).
Shifts the origin of the wind rose for snow redistribution and slope simulations: e.g. choose 45° to have NE/SE/SW/NW (default: 0)
Use the provided incoming long wave on virtual slopes too? (default: FALSE)
Fallback temperature threshold for rain/snow transition if no other spliting method is provided (as data generator). (Default: 1.2°C)
Tell the model that relative humidity values are with respect to water regardless of the temperature (default: TRUE)
If ENFORCE_MEASURED_SNOW_HEIGHTS, relative humidity threshold for precipitation to occur (default: 0.5)
If ENFORCE_MEASURED_SNOW_HEIGHTS, (TA-TSS)' threshold for precipitation to occur (default: 3.0°C)
Air temperature threshold above which no surface hoar is allowed to form (default: 1.2°C)
Relative humidity threshold above which no surface hoar is allowed to form (because at very high humidity, typically no hoar crystals can form). (Default: 0.97)
Wind speed threshold above which no surface hoar is allowed to form (because it will drift away). (Default: 3.5 m/s)
Define the initial density for surface hoar at the time it gets buried by new snow (default: 125 kg/m³)
Define a threshold below which any traces of surface hoar will not be given a separate hoar layer when buried (default: 2.0 mm)
Assumed density of surface hoar while exposed at the surface and not buried (default: 100 kg/m³)

positions of temperatur sensors in snow or soil: positive values refer to heigths measured from the ground surface (snow only), negative values refer to depths measured from either the ground surface or the snow surface in case no soil layers are present. A sensor must at least be covered by MIN_DEPTH_SUBSURF (m) snow for its temperature to be output.
Minimum snow depth (m) above a temperature sensor to accept the measurement (default: 0.07 m)

Water transport model to use in snow: simple bucket model (default), Nied model or Richards equation solver

Lower boundary condition for Richards equation solver (default: FREEDRAINAGE): <dl> <dt>FREEDRAINAGE</dt> <dd>(default, recommended for shallow soil) prescribes a free drainage boundary;</dd> <dt>WATERTABLE</dt> <dd>(recommended for deep soil) prescribes a saturated lower boundary;</dd> <dt>DIRICHLET</dt> <dd>keeps the saturation in the lowest layer constant;</dd> <dt>GRAVITATIONALDRAINAGE</dt> <dd>prescribes the gravity compenent of the liquid water flow;</dd> <dt>SEEPAGE</dt> <dd>provides a seepage boundary condition which typically describes the setup of laboratory experiments;</dd> </dl>

If TRUE, allow the water and ice content in the soil layers to be modified upon model initialization, in order to (1) minimize liquid water flow at the first time step by initializing pressure head (and thus soil water content) in an approximate steady state, and (2) achieve thermal equilibrium between the ice and liquid water part for a given temperature (default: FALSE).

Select calculation method for hydraulic conductivity in frozen soil:
IGNORE
(default) ignore the effect of ice on hydraulic conductivity;
OMEGA7
applies the omega method (see Eq. 6 in Hansson et al., 2004), with omega=7. To use other values of omega, set OMEGAx in the ini file with x the requested value (e.g., OMEGA2.5 sets omega to 2.5);
LIQUIDPORESPACE
calculates the hydraulic conductivity using the saturation determined using the liquid water part only;
Note that OMEGA7 has often a stronger effect than LIQUIDPORESPACE and frequently inhibits downward percolation so much that the solver becomes numerically unstable.

Water transport model to use in soil: simple bucket model (default) or Richards equation solver. Note that Richards equation solver uses the grain size of the layer to determine the soil type, as listed at: https://snowpack.slf.ch/Soil-with-Richards-equation.
More detailed (and stable) solving of the phase changes together with the liquid water transport at the cost of higher computation time? (default: FALSE)

For models intercomparisons, it is possible to replace the energy balance model by a degree-day model during the melt phases. This degree-day model provides the energy fluxes at the surface as: <center>temp_index_degree_day*(T<sub>air</sub> - T<sub>surface</sub>) + temp_index_swr_factor*SW<sub>net</sub></center>
If a positive value is given, the degree-day model is enabled and this is the temperature factor.
If using a degree-day model, it is possible to enhance it with an Incoming Short Wave Radiation dependency. This provides the ISWR factor to use.
Choice of parameterizations for new snow density (statistical models, default: LEHNING_NEW)
Set to 1 kg m-3 to use surface snow density in case of missing measurement values (default: 100 kg/m³)
Usual range used in SNOWPACK : 30 to 250 kg m-3. 30 kg m-3 will be enforced as minimum (default: 100 kg/m³)
New snow density scheme. By default, Snowpack uses "PARAMETERIZED". If selecting "MEASURED", the new snow density must be provided under the parameter name "RHO_HN".

Average value of regression models. ALL_DATA (default) is the average of all albedo values obtained from four SwissMetNet stations: Weissfluhjoch (WFJ, 2540 m asl), Davos (DAV, 1594 m asl), Napf (NAP, 1404 m asl), and Payerne (PAY, 490 m asl). CUSTOM is the mean of the albedo averages for each single station WFJ, DAV, and PAY; it better fits stations lying below 1500 m asl in Switzerland

Use a multi layer SK38 index as in (Monti, Fabiano, et al., "Snow instability evaluation: calculating the skier-induced stress in a multi-layered snowpack", Natural Hazards and Earth System Sciences, 16.3, 2016). (default: FALSE)

Default: FALSE. If true, solves the phase changes iteratively with the heat equation to better deal with freezing point depressions from salinity (SEAICE simulations). Forced to true for SEAICE and RICHARDSEQUATION.
Identify grass growing under the snow height sensor. This usually works well but might sometimes lead to problems (therefore it defaults to FALSE)

Switch to tell the model that a impermeable layer should be simulated on top of some snow or ice: this requires that the *.sno file contains this layer, which is characterized via the soil parameters; the option has successfully been used to simulate snow and ice protection using geo-textiles and saw dust (default: FALSE).
If switched on, you can also simulate ponding on impermeable ice surfaces below the snow cover (default: FALSE)

This flag behaves differently depending on the chosen water transport scheme. For the BUCKET scheme: Assuming an impermeable surface such as on a road or on geo-textiles (e.g. for snow farming), a liquid water layer is allowed to form on this surface. For RICHARDSEQUATION: in case high infiltration fluxes cannot be fully absorbed by the matrix, form a ponding layer on the top of the domain. Default: FALSE
Standard size (m) of a new element added to the stack of elements (layers) during snowfall events (default: 0.02 m)
Threshold value for enforcing the layer to be merged with the layer above or below (default: 0.0025 m)
Combine neighboring elements based on a set of similarity conditions which are hard-coded (default: TRUE)

The canopy is divided into a trunk layer and a leaf-layer. An energy balance is computed for each layer, producing leaf-layer and trunk layer temperatures that affect LW radiations to the ground. Default: TRUE

Computes the canopy shade soil cover fraction, as function of canopy height, crown diameter, vertical canopy soil cover, and solar elevation angle (default: TRUE)
Litter falling on the forest floor can reduce albedo (default: TRUE)
